newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Italy's Prodi returns fire against industrialists.
newsitem.headline: Italy's Prodi returns fire against industrialists.

text.p: Prime Minister Romano Prodi lashed out at Italy's industrial elite on Friday, accusing them of unprecedented meddling in domestic politics.

"Never before in a highly developed country have we seen private industry interfere so heavily in the political life of that country," Prodi told reporters in Dublin where he is attending a summit of European Union leaders.

Relations between Prodi's seven-month old government and employers' organisation Confindustria have deteriorated rapidly in recent weeks, with industrialists up in arms over the 1997 austerity budget.
The chairman of car giant Fiat, Cesare Romiti, on Thursday launched a scathing attack on the Prodi administration.

"Italy is going through a tragic moment," Romiti told a conference in Milan. "The political class is poor in terms of personalities...and Italians realise they don't have a crumb of hope for the future," he added.
Earlier this week, Confindustria chief Giorgio Fossa said the government risked being blown away and urged it to drop planned tax hikes in the 1997 budget.
But Prodi said the industrialists were showing "political immaturity".
"It is because they realise that this government is going to last," he said.
The 1997 budget is currently being examined by parliament which has until the end of the year to approve the deficit cutting package.
